did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle:
Charlie Seemann collection of photographs of vaqueros and gauchos
1985-1986

corpname.part: Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: From November 2-13, 1985, folklorist Charlie Seemann led a group of six volunteers for the California-based Center for Field Research to document vaqueros in the Concepción area of Paraguay and a horse trading operation near Asunción. Photographs documented vaqueros at work, their dress, horses, cattle, gear, and saddles. Additionally, Seemann documented the estancia haciendas, ranch buildings, corrals and fencing, landscapes, and ranch life (175 color slides from Paraguay). From September 12-25, 1986, Charlie Seemann led a similar trip to document guachos in Uruguay at the Estancia San Pedro de Timote, and near Melo, Uruguay. This group traveled to Bagé, in southern Brazil, to observe and document the Dia Do Gaúcho festival, started in 1848 to commemorate the gaúchos who fought in Guerra Dos Farrapos, or War of the Rags. The festival included a parade of some 3,000 mounted gaúchos, music, food, dance, and an outdoor Catholic mass for mounted gaúchos (60 color slides from Brazil). The group returned to Paysandú, Uruguay, and documented the estancia of Hubert Maness, Los Mortreros, near Mercedes on the Rio Negro (138 total color slides from Uruguay). The collection includes Charlie Seemann's original field notes (25 pages).

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the following series: 1. Field notes; 2. Paraguay photographs; 3. Uruguay photographs; 4. Brazil photographs.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Jesse Hocking.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
Collection is open for research; access to collection materials may be restricted. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact

altformavail.head: Electronic Format
altformavail.p: Digital surrogates of manuscript materials (25 pages) are available.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Charlie Seemann collection of photographs of vaqueros and gauchos (AFC 2018/001), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p:
Charlie Seemann is a former executive director of the Western Folklife Center in Elko, Nevada, and a former member of the American Folklife Center Board of Trustees. He holds an M.A. in folklife studies from the University of California, Los Angeles and has served extensively as a folklorist including at the Country Music Foundation, the American Folklife Center, and the National Council for the Traditional Arts. He is the co-editor of the book
Folklife and Museums: Selected Readings
and has produced and/or annotated more than 30 documentary albums of folk, country, and cowboy music. In 1983, he received a Wrangler Award from the National Cowboy Hall of Fame and Western Heritage Museum and a Grammy nomination for the New World Records anthology
Back in the Saddle Again: American Cowboy Songs
. In 2003 he received a second Wrangler award for producing
Buck Ramsey: Hittin' the Trail
. He has written numerous articles on western culture and cowboy music.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: From November 2-13, 1985, folklorist Charlie Seemann led a group of six volunteers for the California-based Center for Field Research to document vaqueros in the Concepción area of Paraguay and a horse trading operation near Asunción. Photographs documented vaqueros at work, their dress, horses, cattle, gear, and saddles. Additionally, Seemann documented the estancia haciendas, ranch buildings, corrals and fencing, landscapes, and ranch life (175 color slides from Paraguay). From September 12-25, 1986, Charlie Seemann led a similar trip to document guachos in Uruguay at the Estancia San Pedro de Timote, and near Melo, Uruguay. This group traveled to Bagé, in southern Brazil, to observe and document the Dia Do Gaúcho festival, started in 1848 to commemorate the gaúchos who fought in Guerra Dos Farrapos, or War of the Rags. The festival included a parade of some 3,000 mounted gaúchos, music, food, dance, and an outdoor Catholic mass for mounted gaúchos (60 color slides from Brazil). The group returned to Paysandú, Uruguay, and documented the estancia of Hubert Maness, Los Mortreros, near Mercedes on the Rio Negro (138 total color slides from Uruguay). The collection includes Charlie Seemann's original field notes (25 pages).
